info.document:
MUSKEGON, MI - Women's Equality Day was celebrated in Muskegon Thursday with the recognition of several women who continue to champion equal rights and social justice.

The celebration featured a keynote address by attorney Dana Nessel, who recently announced her candidacy as a Democrat for state attorney general, and has been recognized for her work on behalf of lesbian, gay and transgender rights.

Several awards were bestowed at the Equality Day celebration:

The Bread and Roses award was given to Donna Secor-Pennington for her work related to the lead poisoning of water in Flint and her support of women running for public office.

The Young Feminist Award was given to Jocelyn Hines, Amanda Clark and Elissa Chalker. Hines, whose activism began when she was in college, has been a key organizer of Muskegon County's new Young Black Professionals organization. Clark and Chalker have organized protest marches and continue to work for social justice.

The Nevertheless She Persisted Award, a one-time special award, was presented to Nancy Sanders for her work in communicating important issues to local and state lawmakers.

Special recognition, the "Profiles in Courage Award," was given to U.S. Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, and U.S. Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, for voting to maintain health care coverage for millions of Americans.
